From fixing radios as a kid to winning the Nobel prize in physics, Surely You're Joking Mr. Feynman covers Feynman's life and adventures in chronological order. I liked when Feynman asks for a map of a cat  (he really wanted a zoological chart of a cat).  I thought the book was really funny and  enjoyed how no parts of the book are really sad. Feynman acts like a child testing how much he can get away with.

Among the senior science students, this book needs no introduction. Good for its style of presentation and explanation of the simple facts that we think we knew, and yet far from the correct. I could read this book in a span of one week, and read many more times, and yet to read many more times, to get what the author intends to say. Myself being a Physics graduate, feels this book as indispensible.

I am an avid reader of physics biography and autobiography and this is by far the best I have ever read. This is a must read for anyone in a physics or a science field. Stories of being a world class scientist inspire while portraying the interesting life he lead in his spare time. Not only a story about a brilliant man but a great adventure though life of a man who lived life to the fullest.

I only wish that I could have taken a class from Richard Feynman.  This is not a book about physics.  It is a book about of the most brilliant physics minds of the last century and a good guy to boot.  It is a book that I have read to my kids (the chapters are each an episode or incident in feynman's life and are hilarious, touching, and insightful).  I can not recommend this book too highly.

Fantastic book of short life stories.  I am not a "physics" guy but all these tales, even the ones with hard core science, were easily accessible.  The writing style is fantastic and you really get to know the author so well.  He was a great writer, scientist, and human being.  Some of the way he deals with his personal life are... odd -- but it only adds to his quirky scientist persona.

This is an excellent read.  If you're looking to get a first person perspective from the mind of one of the world's quirkiest, most brilliant physicists, look no further.  His anecdotes are both intriguing and influential.  He not only inspires you to become a better thinker, but he also instills a message of how to stay humble when you hit your intellectual peak.  Absolutely fantastic.

I really enjoyed this book, though I only listened to it on tape. It was a worthwhile read/listen. The stories are fun even if you don't understand the physics. I suggest that anyone read this book, whether scientifically inclined or otherwise. I'm actually 13, and I found the book an enjoyable read. My parents and younger brother all enjoyed it equally. A great book for any age.

Feynman was one of the finest teacher, thinker and physicist of our time. His theory on Quantum Elctrodynamics earned him nobel prize in 1965. But, I think his best contribution to the society was his passion for teaching. This book takes you through his character beautifully. All stories in the book suggest some beautiful aspect of this man's life. Really a must read. 10 on 10.

I bought this book on a whim because it was about a famous scientist, who built much of the foundation for what I was studying. I opened it up while taking a break from my physics homework and.. needless to say I couldn't put it down. I read it in one day. The mixture of his adventures being intertwined with his work on quantum theory was better then anything I've ever read.

This book is absolutely Fabulous. Mr. Feynman is either a liar (which he's not), or he has led one of the most interesting lives of any American I know. His stories hit a special cord with me because his story telling reminds me of my Grandfather, Pap Bud. He worked with the greatest scientists in human history and, in the end, became one. It leaves you totally inspired.

I really loved this book so I bought one for my dad, who also loved it.  Feynman is a great writer, and has a lot of interesting and funny stories in his book.  The book also, isn't very scientific, which makes it nice if you're reading it for leisure.  I also really liked his method for squaring numbers in his head.  It's definitely helped me with my mental math.

A good friend loaned me this and I enjoyed it so much I bought one for my father at Christmas.  He loved it as much as I did.  It is more than an autobiography of a truly stunning intellect.  Mr Feynman's curiosity is contagious and has caused me to open my eyes and question why things are the way they are.  The stories are hilarious.  I hope you enjoy it too.
If you're a scientist or a physician or any other related activity, you can't have any more fun than reading this book. It will give you the freedom to do things a different way.
Even for the non-scientist, such as myself, this is great collection of stories from the Nobel prize winning Feynman. What a life this man led. It's a shame he couldn't live forever.

You should only hope the science minded grads on your gift list will have a professor or two an eighth as fascinating as Dr. Feynmann.  Whether you take milk or lemon in your tea, you will adore this excentric, loveable, probably Asperger's genius.
A brilliant man with an affable disposition regales readers with stories of his life's adventures. Absolutely delightful reading from beginning to end!
I enjoyed learning about this gentleman very much. He seems to be fascinating in his field and personal pursuits. This is a book definitely worth reading.

Good read for traveling. Not an autobiography by any means, more a collection of stories somewhat arranged chronologically. Not much regarding details of his professional accomplishments, this book is more about what went on outside of the classrooms, labs and offices.

If you're looking for a book about physics, this isn't it.  Feynman comes across as thoroughly human, maybe a bit too much so -- his tales of womanizing are a bit off-putting and his strange diversions into percussion were distracting, but overall a good read.
Step into the mind of a truly one-of-a-kind thinker. This should be required relaxing for anyone who has even the slightest interest of how things work!

Have just finished reading for the third time. I always learn some sort of life lesson I had not learned before. Recommend this highly as a light and interesting read for anyone, and in particular to everyone studying any science.

Feynman is very funny and charming in this biography.  The stories sometimes seem far fetched and slightly egotistical, but that is just his personality.  For example, stories on how he picked up a girl by being an ass, or how he quit drinking cold turkey because he thought he was becoming an alcoholic.  Overall I enjoyed the read.

My physics teacher gave me this to read back in high school and I loved it.  Ten years later, I just finished reading it again and it's just as clever, funny, and thought provoking as ever.  An excellent read!
People should read this  to understand how thins work not just in physics but every day life.  I think it should be required reading for independant thinkers.

Do yourself a favor and watch a youtube clip of RF giving a speech.  Listen for at least 5 minutes.  It won't take much to absorb his rather unique style of speaking into your consciousness and this will greatly enhance this first person account of his life experiences. Besides making a significant contribution to the Manhattan Project at Los Alomos, and receiving a Nobel Prize, Feynman (pronounced fine-men) constantly developed many varied interests and pursued them passionately.  If asked to give a one word description of the guy, I guess I would use that word - passionate.  There are many interesting passages in the book, and one of the things I really admired about him was his broad view of education, particularly during his graduate studies.  While at Princeton, he met a number of students and professors in departments other than his physics major, and sat in on many of their courses just because he found the subject interesting.  And because he was a brilliant guy, he caught on quickly to basic issues and often made his unique contributions in those fields as well.  And it was interesting times - he was a student in the 30's, at Los Alamos during WWll and taught for years afterwards (and played the drums, and marched at Rio's Carnival, etc.) He mentions his wives briefly but says next to nothing about his kids.  And he had a fondness for women and met a number at clubs and bars.  Not my expectations of a physicist, but an incredibly interesting guy.  What he was not, was a great writer.  When he described problems and solutions, he raced over the details much like his mind thought.  It was impossible to get a clear grasp of what he was trying to communicate in many of these passages.  But then he always preferred speaking to audiences with a depth of knowledge in the field and was frustrated with those that couldn't keep pace.  A great guy but I wouldn't want him for a professor in one of my EE classes.  Four stars is probably a generous rating, but if you only get through a portion of this book you will be glad that you got to experience and know a little bit about Feynman.

I thought this was a very insightful view of a very interesting person.  The snapshots of the different events in his life were entertaining, informative, and well written. This sounds like a teacher who would and, I am sure, has ignited the desire and joy of learning in the lives and minds of his students.
Ramblings from the life of a genius!  This is a very enjoyable look into the emotional brain of an analytical genius.

If you like Feynman than this one is for you, it an autobiography of this truly great man, he had such a fascinating life, I breezed through it in two night's and I was sad when I finished it, I wish it been ten thousand pages long. In short, I loved it, but I am a big admirer of Mr. Feynman.
This is a great autobiographical book by one of the greatest physicists of the 20th century. It's an easy read and not particularly technical. Well worth the time and money.

Rubbing elbows with the most eminent scientists in the world, dabbling in art and music, un-stuffing a military shirt or two, and just having fun in bars, Feynman was about fun and curiosity.  A bit of hyperbole, but always a fast paced tour of his world view and the early stages of his life and career.  Very easy read for me.

Richard Feynman was truly one of our countries finest national treasures.  This journey through many of his life experiences is rich with humor and mind stretching events.  I thoroughly enjoyed this book, and while it may seem a bit dated in some areas, it is well worth the time and investment.  A remarkable man!
Entertaining and illuminating.  A memoir based on a culmination of philosophy, comedy,  scientific thoughts and experiences which was a joy to read.  It demonstrated the human side of brilliance.
Somewhat hard to follow at times but delightful in how innocent it is too. Would not read again. Recommended by science Friday boon club.

Of many thing, the most important trait is the power of observation and free-wheeling spirit to explore and execute. Irrespective of the field, Mr. Feynman sends a strong signal about passion and keen observation. Wonderful book - a must read and should be made a mandatory read during school years - but then it probably will defeat the purpose.
very entertaining reading and of historical interest also.  he was a brilliant man who also was quite down to earth
Feynman shows that even one of the smartest guys ever can have a sense of humor and enjoyment of life.

Any layman (like myself) can enjoy this book despite because it walks us through a journey of how a famous, curious, and fascinating mind worked, not about the technical aspects of Feynman's theories that made him  so successful in the field of physics.  It's a great book for everyone.

It was fun to read the casual writings of such a brilliant man. He certainly had a sense of humor and strong ethics. I had to read both this and "What Do You Care What Other People Think?". I don't think one is complete without the other.
I watched a movie about the space shuttle and looked him up and found his books.  They are e great!
This book is a quick read and it's a lot of fun. It's written by one of the top scientists the world has seen. It is full of humor and interesting anecdotes.
One of my all time favorite books.  An interesting perspective of Richard Feynman which is filled with humor and keeps you smiling.  A must have book for your library.

A highly entertaining read, but more importantly Dick goes into detail to explain how he viewed the world and how to solve problems.  This is one of those books that is a hidden gem for entrepreneurs.
This is a great reading about one of the most interesting, free-spirit, Nobel award winning scientists. Allows to understand the mind behind the technical work.
I loved the story. What riveted me most of all was the closing defense of science against cargo cult imitation science. This should be required reading.
Wish I would have read this when I was in high school, the man is brilliant. Tinkering with everything from an early age.
I was most impressed by the first half of the book, thoroughly enjoyable. It may have tapered off slightly towards the end. Captures well his way of speaking and expressing himself.
A Nobel Laureate and a joker.  One of the best parts is how he cracked the safes at Lon Alomos and Oakridge containing all the secrets of The Bomb.
Must read book describing whole life of Mr Feynman as he telling the stories. Particularly interesting for tech students as Feynman is quite a figure, to spot the way he thinks and works.
You don't have to know anything about physics to delve into the genius and quirky mind of Feynman and love it.

Granted this is a memoir, and it has to be taken with a grain of salt, his life as he tells it is incredible.  To have such a well-rounded life and be a Nobel prize winner is something I aspire to.  And I imagine I will continue aspiring to it until I die.
I'm an undergrad science student. I read this book whenever I feel a bit less motivated than usual... And it always cheers me up without a single failure!

Feynman is my favourite physicist (I am a chemist). What a wonderful, unusual and talented man both scientifically (Nobel prize) and as a person he was. A more non-professorial professor is hard to imagine! Thiis book is a fascinating collection of short tales by him, scientific and otherwise, and is to be heartily recommended.

This book is amazingly entertaining.  It helps to know a little about who Feynman was and what he accomplished in physics but not really necessary. This guy is a wonderful writer and a brilliant man.  If I where king all college freshman would have to read this book.
I highly recommend this book. It's probably not what you are expecting... in a good way. Don't worry the book isn't full of academic knowledge.
This guy had an amazing life. I am glad to have learned more about him. A great read for anyone who loves science.

This book is on my list of ten favorite books of all time, and I have read numerous books during my long life.  Mr. Feynman is highly educated, articulate, informative and funny!!  I have read this book several times, and enjoyed it each and every time.  I did not always understand some of the scrientific information, but he writes in such a way that I always got the gist of what he was saying.  An excellent read.
Muy entretenido. Richard Feynman tiene una manera única de ver a la vida y el aprendizaje, un curioso en todo sentido.

I had meant for many years to read this book.  I find Mr. Feynman's observations about the world and the sciences refreshing and very amusing.  He was a great mind and a truly unique and curious person.  I look forward to reading more of his works.

He wasn't joking when he was asked if he wanted cream or lemon in his tea but his jokes pepper the rest of the book and his pranks impress. It is not just the pranks. Book reads like a biography and it has enough stories for several lives of us lesser mortals.
A rare combination of brilliance and humor along with a dose of humility make this a must read for those of us who actually use our brains to think and experience life.

Anyone whose image of a scientist is that of a dull, timid nerd is in for a delightful shock. Feynman was a Nobel prize-winning physicist who put almost as much effort into learning how to seduce women as he did understanding quantum mechanics. Whether playing strange native musical instruments in a Brazilian street band, or dining with prostitutes in Las Vegas, Feynman's dedication to experiencing life to the fullest comes through loud and clear. The book is funny, informative, and leaves you at least a little bit envious if you haven't been quite so adventureous.
Everyone should read this book. It has so many things in it which are entertaining. I hate books and I love this book. Prof Feynmans life was amazing and worth the read if nothing else.
Very entertaining and informative.  I feel as though I knew the man now.  I intend to read more books about this brilliant man.

Feynman's rambling (and somewhat disjointed) "memoir" provides an entertaining and at time very informative look into both the field of physics and life as he experienced them, through the medium of a succession of anecdotes. Some boring spots, but you get to see who and what he is. Good book for Feynman fans.
It's amazing to get an inside perspective of a genius, and how he isn't all that different from the rest of us.
I heard about Richard Feynman from serval other books and a Ph.D. friend. It more thank lived up to my expectations.

I knew about his work but not about the man.  What an amazing man.  His book is honest without guile!  He truly understood what was important and pointed out the foolish ideas about life and human behavior.  His brain was not wired like most of the population...and that was the gift of evolution and a father that encouraged questions.  Every once in while evolution produces a mind Like Dr Feynman's. Too bad the odds of repeating this evolutionary gift is not on a larger scale.

An amazing gift for anyone in physics but a great read for the layman as well. Feynman is so smart and tells his story in a clever tongue in cheek way that will keep you turning the page late into the night. Couldn't put it down!
Very fun book to read even though many parts are by now very dated. Feynman surely had genius in the field of physics but was also interested in so many other topics it's kind of amazing.
"Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman!" is well written; funny, exciting, science, cultural, internal, and memorable.  I think it is a book for the age of 15 and above.

In addition to being an enjoyable read, this book provides an insight to the mind and behavior of a real genius: Virtually every interaction with a new subject led him to take on and overcome new challenges -- from deep nuclear physics, to new languages, to interactions with Las Vegas call girls. While I have been told I have a pretty keen IQ, Feynman's ability and capacity to take on intellectual challenges leaves me astounded.  It is a gift to us that he has taken the time to record his thoughts and behavior, of which we should stand in awe.
enjoyed the observations and opinions of Mr. Feynman, book was easy read and enjoyable. He was surprisingly candid and opinionated
Feynam possessed an extraordinary intelligence and a unique way of looking at the world. His approach to life is enlightening, eye-opening, and delightful.

This book is a great piece of literature if you are looking to be entertained by the incredible stories of Richard Feynman, the book keeps you constantly entertained as he gets into complex situations but also gives you a hint of the great brilliance of this character, extremely recommended and does not require any knowledge in science.

I really loved this book. Feynman's observations and look at his life. The two most important that stuck with me is his childish curiosity which he cultivated contributed to much of success. This childish curiosity is something I lost, and I am trying to recover.
One of the best books i've read. I recommend it heartily. A fantastic story from a fantastic human, teacher and scientist. I could only wish to be able to understand the world as he did !

This book assembles autobiographical anecdotes that Feynman published a few years before his death at the early age of 70.  Very lightly written, very enjoyable, and sheds light on a special likeable character who is extremely talented in many areas.  Nobel laureate - but in many respects so much one of us mortals.

This is a fun and exciting read for anyone wanting to know more about Richard Feynman the man. He opens his life up to you and gives you a way to see through his eyes. Those looking for an in-depth discussion of physics will be disappointed, however they will be entertained! Read Feynman in love, Feynman the musician, the student, the traveler, the philosopher, the artist, the womanizer and most of all the scientist and person that is Feynman. From scientist to layman, anyone would have fun reading this book, don't let me spoil it anymore, go and read it for yourself!

I loved this book. You really get the sense of Richard Feynman's character from this memoir. He was incredibly smart but also insatiably curious. He was interested in everything and was the archetypal "life-hacker". Some other reviewers consider this book to be an example of Feynman's arrogance and self-importance. I couldn't disagree more. He comes across as playfully curious about everything and (of course) good at many things but he is as surprised as anyone at how good he can be at something with a little effort. Going to another country? Learn the language. Want to open a safe? Learn how they work. Like pictures? Learn how to draw. We need more Feynmans in the world.

I thought it was a wonderful autobiography because Feynman shared all his comical incidents and how he progressed as a physicist at the same time.  Not only did I laugh out loud, but I know a lot more about physics!  Overall, I recommend this book to anyone who wants to learn about an  incredible personality and the genius of Richard Feynman.

This book shows the person behind the Genius. His fiddling around with things and people, and so on and so forth.. You can actually hear his voice while you read his stories, from the kid who fixes radios by thinking to the safecracker in Los Alamos. He shows a little of how he thinks about the world, in a very amusing way. I just love it.

One of my favorites! He was definitely a womanizer, though, and there is a particularly misogynistic chapter near the end that will upset some. When put in historical context it's more understandable, but it was off-putting nonetheless. That being said, this is a classic and an incredibly fun read. You will probably even learn something.

It is without doubt one of the best books I've ever read. Besides being amusing and easy to read, it teaches you a lot about science and the way it should be approached. His life is an example to follow, and his  autobiography is the best I've seen so far. I strongly recomend it to  everybody, you don't have to be a scientist to read it!

This book is quite original, the intro of a innocent curiosity with radios, takes a turn into the literal. He outlines his lifes path, painted from a technical and non-chalant standpoint, and vividly spins a yarn about ivy league colleges, a inner circle of mathemeticians, physicists and science in the round. Sincerely a good read.

Bought this book on a whim, and gave it a read. I have to say, this book makes it quite clear that Feynman even at a very early age was something of an oddball and not just a product of "good parenting." He somehow evolved a unique way of looking at things, and the book is filled with many very short memoirs of his life experiences.

After finishing a heavy book, I wanted some light reading. This book was the perfect choice, and I have been recommending it to my friends. Feynman's book is fun, easy to read, filled with humor and wit and, occasionally, you catch a glimpse of his amazing intellect. I have thoroughly enjoyed this book, and I think you will too.

This book is extremely entertaining, but there's a lot more to it than that.  Feynman is my hero, and  after reading this book, he'll probably be yours too, but at the very least you'll feel like changing yourself after  you read the book. I'm applying to Duke University, and I'm writing an  essay about how this book changed me.

Excellent book about Richard Feynman. Don't worry, it's not technical at all and is simply about his journey to becoming one of the top physicists of our time. He came across as a very down to earth perso; someone you could meet in a bar and have no idea who he was or what he'd accomplished. I would love to have met him!

What an interesting and thought provoking book by someone who had a truly amazing life. Even as I laughed over some of the crazy anecdotes Feynman tells, I was impressed and inspired by his never-ending intellectual curiosity. After reading Feynman's story, I hope to incorporate more of that into my own life.

The presence of the greatest teacher (both in life and physics) can be felt intensely through this book. Surely, Your Joking Mr. Feynman is a comical and interesting book about Mr. Feynman's life and his passion Physics. In this book he talks very in-depthly about his life everything from his very early childhood years to his adult life as a professor. The book is very well written with just enough detail to make you interested in all of his adventures, but not too much that you would loose interest. This book does not use complex equations or terms to explain physics terms, but creatively words each concept so that any level of reader and physics explorer could understand what he was doing. Giving this book great word choice and a nice flow that keeps you wanting to read along. Through all of this, the book is comically written and tells about Mr. Feynman's crazy experiments and pranks he played on people. Everything from hiding a door from a member of his fraternity to casually moving around the information for the atomic bomb from safe to safe. Mr. Feynman thrives on crazy adventures through the physics world and does many crazy things along the way to satisfy his hunger for comedy. This book is recommended for anyone who enjoys a good educational book, but also has a good sense of humor and enjoys practical jokes themselves.

Even though I did not always understand everything (I was bad in physics), and even though I found the last chapter boring, I felt the book was brilliant. I often laughed out loud, and often felt inspired by the genius and humility of Feynman. Highly recommend to everyone

Mr. Feynman's career as a physicist was remarkable, including highlights such as the Manhattan Project and the inquiry into the Challenger Space Shuttle disaster.  This collection of anecdotes gives us a look at another side of this distinguished scientist.  Here we find an irreverent person, who enjoyed practical jokes and loved to explore interests beyond science.  Many of these stories are extremely funny, while others are thought provoking.  If there is lesson here, it is that we should live our lives like explorers, always pushing the limits of our experience and never afraid to take chances.
It is a very interesting and inspiring book. Richard Feynman was a very clever and unique man. I think reading this book is a wonderful way to invest your time.

He can tell a story, but unabashed egotism comes through in every line.Being the scientific genius that he is, I thought he would have enough self-awareness to rise above that.  The sexism in some of the stories was amusing. Reading his stories about women is like listening to a radio show from the 50's. He was a male living the dream in the 40's and 50's, and some stories you're just waiting for him to start talking about "dames".

Although Mr. Feynman is undoubtedly a smart man, with many things to credit to his name, this book seemed like nothing but his attempt to show how smart he was and is.  However he comes off as extremely arrogant and pompous, the problem being that his anecdotes are ruined by his comments on how stupid others are compared to himself.  Almost every other paragraph is a story in which he felt he outsmarted someone, but in reality, his accomplishments seem very exaggerated and insignificant.  The way he talks about not being considered a sissy by struggling against his frat brothers, outsmarted the waitress with dumb puzzles, and outwitted his frat when stealing a door are NOT impressive in the least, and I feel that a average person could accomplish the same things.  The fact that he writes about it in a manner so that he tries to make himself some child genius is what ruins the book and makes him seem stupider rather than smarter.  I'm sorry Mr. Feynman, you may be a great physicist, but you must be joking if you think you're a writer, and a clever one at that.  I may not be able to solve physics problems like you, but I can assure you...I am much more clever if compared to your life stories (and that's not saying much).

Although I'd heard of Feynman for years now--people I know were excited by the Feynman Lectures volumes--I didn't really know who he was. Oh, I could probably have given you the fact that he was a physicist, and maybe that he had won the Nobel prize, and just recently Jill told me about a Feynman anecdote that she had read by Stephen Jay Gould. After Surely You're Joking, I know much more about Feynman, and why he interests people. As far from the stereotype of the scientist that you can get, yet still having some geeky characteristics that he wasn't afraid to admit to, Surely You're Joking is a portrait of the man in his own words. In fact, the best way to approach this book is as if you had stumbled on to it in a dimly-lit bar, sat down next to it, exchanging turns buying drinks and talking about each other. Just like a conversation, some things are funny, some things don't make sense, and--as a one-sided conversation--they all revolve around a singe subject.

This series of anecdotes about the life of physicist Richard Feynman is a a great read for anyone, even if you have no interest in science.  It definitely makes this scientist seem more human, but illuminates his brilliance in everyday affairs.

Don't pay any attention to that negative review by "Zorba", whose knowledge of post-war bar culture is probably limited.  And his appraisal of Feynman's practical jokes being hurtful must be based on something other than this book.  Feynman has some funny stories and provides us with some biographical data along the way to give the stories a setting.  We hear about his childhood and his first job, along with his early fascination with gadgets and inventions.  Not much in the way of specific details on his work in physics, as has been provided in other biographies, and the "Feynman diagrams, which show the arrows of light and time, are mentioned not-a-once, nor is it detailed exactly what he won the nobel prize for, though his headaches of receiving the prize are amuzing.  Don't look for physics, but for the social life of a physicist who also happened to be a character.  He does talk about physics and math and education in a general way and offers up some general observations about how people approach these subjects. There are stories from Los Alamos to Brazil and Japan and from CalTech and Princeton.  A fun short read, if that's what you're looking for.
While I have no doubt the author and his fans are enjoying themselves immensely, I simply didn't get it.  No harm there.  I wish them continued happiness and joy on all fronts!

I can't see why so many idiots give Feynman's books bad reviews and say "the guy is OVERRATED man!"  These people are probably just jealous because Feynman was UNDOUBTEDLY the coolest smart-person who ever lived.  Moreover, this is the book which provides conclusive proof of that fact.  Anyone who says Feynman was overrated is blatantly wrong -- In fact, I have been interning at the Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Lab, where I met a man named Don Thompson who actually met Feynman when he did his post-doctoral work at Caltech.  As Don says, "Feynman was just as funny, brilliant, and vibrant as all the books and accounts say he was."  So, buy this book, and don't believe all the idiots who give it bad reviews.

One of our times' most well known physicists tells some supposedly amusing anecdotes from his life in 'Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman!', but in many cases I fail to see the humor. The writing is rather pedestrian, but  the author does not purport to create great literature, only to amuse. Some  of these anecdotes can be described as funny, but in many of the stories  Feynman shows a glaring lack of empathy with his fellow man, and seems to  be completely unaware of his shortcoming in this respect. Feynman was among  other things involved in the Manhattan project, and if this is what passed  for humor among the people who created the bomb, their moral stance (or  lack thereof) becomes more tangible. It is a very chilling realization.

Clearly Mr. Feynman is brilliant, but he comes off as a self-aggrandizing jerk; always having to show that he's smarter than anyone else and playing 'jokes' on people that they probably didn't find so funny.  Would I want to hang out with someone like that?  Nope!  Then why waste my time reading all of his clever anectodes?
